replies.context: Lidar and utilization of mesh computer networks to provide locational accuracy in areas not well covered by GPS is actually pretty cool use of technology... I am not sure why it is generally being ridiculed here. I'll agree that drones in general can and probably will be really problematic from a privacy perspective, and also that there are a lot of bad uses and bad pilot/ owners out there, but there are some positives, too. This could be one of them.

it is being ridiculed because we already knew that... hell, they used balloons in the civil war to spot enemy troops, using a drone has been used for a decade by the military even as attack vehicles...so someone realizing it could be used to find lost hikers, or their dog in their back yard does not need a scientist to bring it to our attention.... wow,

So, that isn't the same as lidar, which is what the article is talking about. That technology can see through thick canopies, which is why it is innovative. Go to a heavily wooded area in a balloon with your binoculars (you can even wear your civil war uniform) and look straight down. Many times, you will only see foliage.  Lidar can help with that, can actually identify objects beneath that canopy. I am not saying it is the second coming, but it is a cool use of the technology. Same is true of using mesh networks. I agree 100% that this isn't a heavy hitting article full of insight, but I fail to see why it is worthy of so much vitriol. Put another way, you say "we already knew that", but could you personally coordinate a group of drone technology to locate a target in a remote location where GPS is sketchy through heavy canopy? I couldn't, and I think it is cool that these kids are.  That is my point.... why ridicule someone that is working to improve and understand things?

Better have a strong battery life. The typical 20-minute flight time won't help finding anyone.

I think it is a great idea.  Would be nice if it had the ability to allow two way communications.  I was lost in CO. hiking a 14K footer in August 2018, I made a mistake coming down in the dark.  A drone flew up to me (about 10 feet away), stayed there for about 1 minute, maybe longer and then flew off.  Left me in the dark lost.  It would have been nice if I could have spoke to it and whoever was flying it. (Military or on Auto pilot I suspect, very professional drone).

Lucky I had compass and map and eventually found my way.

A hiker really should not get lost if prepared. I hiked the Sierras by myselft for 20 years until i was 76.  Made a 3D map of the hike, used GPS and compass.   Informed my children of the hike and expected exit of the hike. Talked to other hikers before i started to determine if taking the same route and their expected ETD and carried adequate water and small first aid kit.  Sounds like a lot of work, but it wasn't.  After 100+ hikes preparation was automatic.
